seo.title: Safety and Humanity in the Age of AI
seo.prose: Today I'm going to be talking about a topic that I think everyone can appreciate: namely how can we most palatably deal with the rise of AI that seems and is everywhere. Well, first of all the hard pill we have to swallow is that AI is inevitable --- it's not quite a bubble, but is over-hyped at times --- and it will infiltrate every aspect of our life within years (probably less than 15 to be conservative). Once we accept that, we naturally wonder how we should deal with that. My thesis is we need Safety and we need Humanity, realized in certain ways, to make this a future worth having.

pageTitle: Safety and Humanity in the Age of AI

knowledgeTree.prose: So I'd like to start with Safety, as we've all heard this a countless number of times, Safety First, though I think you'll agree that we've also ignored that same another countless number of times.  But probably my favorite example of Safety in practice because it is so singularly exciting, fascinating, and terrifying at the same time is the Apollo 11 Moon Landing in 1969. This was really the epitome of a 0-1 situation: either boots touch the lunar surface or they don't. And there were a million very plausible ways you could fail. Add to that the national and scientific pressure and prestige, the fact that 3 highly valuable and respected human lives were at stake, and oh yes the whole world is watching on live TV. But the people at NASA really thought hard about this and prepared incredibly well for a huge number of failure scenarios, the vast majority of which thankfully never showed a hint of occuring. And you know they have their list of safety and engineering guidelines, of course, but I think of it from my perspective and it seems to me you can collect all that safety preparation in 3 principles which probably applies to any large, fault-tolerant system or mission, in particular our own mission to come to grips with AI. But I call these out as Frequent Recalibration, Loose Coupling, and a Backup Plan for Everything.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/agc.jpg
widgets.title: Frequent Recalibration
widgets.subtitle: (no system is perfectly calibrated)
widgets.notes:
⦿  Even the best-designed systems can drift/go-out-of-whack 

 ⦿  e.g. continual recalibration of Apollo Guidance Computer (AGC) 
 without updating Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU), errors accumulate unacceptably 
 https://space.stackexchange.com/questions/31279/how-was-the-apollo-imu-calibrated 

 ⦿  e.g., 10% thrust for 30s to measure spaceship stability (P63 landing phase, 50k ft alt.)  

 ⦿  e.g. with AI, constantly re-evaluate our alignment
widgets.prose: So first, Frequent Recalibration. No system, no matter how well-designed, stays true to its purpose forever. It needs to be tuned and readjusted. And in the Apollo Mission nothing exhibited this more poignantly than the AGC, the Apollo Guidance Computer. It's a really beautiful 32kg chunk of copper and electronics, with this little interactive panel called the DSKY. There's a link here to a great lecture on this computer and a lot of what it did during the mission --- and believe me it got out of whack in numerous ways. In particular its  IMU (Inertial Measurement Unit) reported the spacecraft's orientation, which is crucial to anything you're doing out there, and it had to be continually aligned via astronauts looking out the window and reading star positions with a sextant -- yes just like ancient mariners. Another great example of this was during the so-called P63 landing phase when the spacecraft was in position to lower to the surface at a controlled speed via its thrusters. Now remember you're falling rapidly towards the lunar surface at 5000ft altitude and you really do need to slow down, but you just don't fire the thrusters and hope for the best --- you measure and calibrate first, by firing at 10% thrust and observing whether the spacecraft rotates. If there is any rotation, you then adjust the position before retrying this exercise, and then eventually going to maximum thrust (actually 94%, but there's another safety reason for that). So recalibration --- obviously incredibly important for safety. Likewise with AI in our lives, we need to constantly recalibrate where we're going and how fast.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/gemini.jpeg
widgets.title: Loose Coupling
widgets.subtitle: (learn to accommodate imperfection)
widgets.notes:
⦿  dilute single points of failure 

 ⦿  interrupt domino effects 

 ⦿  e.g. Gemini spacecraft magnetic docking 

 ⦿  e.g. with AI, Human-in-the-Loop
widgets.prose: The next principle I call Loose Coupling, or try to accommodate imperfection everywhere. And again I think a great example from the Apollo mission was the way the Gemini spacecraft would dock with a Target Vehicle -- I mean you have these two massive hunks of metal floating in space, how do you get them to couple together with sub-millimeter precision? And there's even a game here you can play to try this yourself in a simulation, it's quite challenging (I've done it at Kennedy Space Center I think) as you need to get the two ends very close without crashing into eachother, but the key is that they don't need to be perfectly aligned because you have magnets here that pull them to perfect alignment within a certain distance. You accommodate the imperfect way the human is inevitably going to steer these things. So what you've done here with this arrangement is you've smoothed out a possible single point of failure, i.e. the spacecraft misaligning with and damaging its docking station, which would you know scrap the whole mission. So when components need to come together, you make it soft. Likewise in our relationship with AI, we need to emphasize soft interfaces. Human-in-the-loop, which I talked about in my last INFORMS talk 10 years ago, you've all heard of by now, and is a great example of that.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/Apollo_Pad_Abort_Test_-2.jpg
widgets.title: A Backup Plan for Everything
widgets.subtitle: don't be caught without a parachute (or two)
widgets.notes:
⦿  e.g. Apollo Launch Escape System 

 ⦿  e.g. in AI, have low/no-tech backups
widgets.prose: My final principle, I call have a Backup Plan for Everything. And that should be familiar to everyone in some way or another. Again in the Apollo mission, countless backup plans. My favorite here is called the Apollo Launch Escape System, which is a little side thruster that fires in case something were to go wrong with the enormous Saturn rocket: you want to decouple the lunar module and get the astronauts as quickly away as possible from the possibly-going-to-explode Saturn rocket, and sideways is your best bet. In AI, an example of a Plan B would be to have low or no-tech backup solutions, because if the AI has failed, then you can't trust any of the technology behind it which is probably controlling everything else hi-tech. And we'll get back to discuss this point later.

children.prose: Now, despite all our great safety principles and enjoyment of an increasingly long and healthy lifespan in step, there's an awful amount of backlash against Safety. Whether it's mockery for being overly cautious, or pride in shirking safety, or indignance against protocol, Safety doesn't have the perfect reputation it deserves.

children.prose: Now I want to say one more thing about Safety from the perspective of a Physicist. And that is that many of the things we associate with Safety, like determinism, reproducibility, stability, are central tenets of Classical Physics.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/action.png
widgets.title: Classical Physics = Minimal Action
widgets.notes:
• S = <KE> – <PE> is minimal 

 • Energy is Conserved at All Times 

 • Deterministic Motion 

 • Only One Path between A and B 

 • e.g., ballistics, orbital motion, electricity, fluids, etc.
widgets.prose: You see, there is this principle in classical mechanics of Minimal Action. This basically says that in any process the average difference between kinetic and potential energy, the action, is the smallest it could ever be. When you throw a ball up in the air, it takes the path it does precisely because it minimizes this action. Now it also takes that path, which many of you remember can be a parabola, due to Newton's Laws of Motion, and it turns out that is equivalent. But the Minimal Action Principle is a much mor elegant way of saying it, and it is useful in understanding something beyond Classical Physics, namely Quantum Physics.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/quantum.png
widgets.title: Quantum Physics = Measured Deviations from Classical
widgets.subtitle: (measured by Planck's Constant, h)
widgets.notes:
• S = <KE> – <PE> swings around minimum 

 • Energy Can Be Violated (for short times) 

 • Non-Deterministic Motion 

 • Many Paths between A and B (all coexist) 

 • e.g., decay of a Uranium atom, Casimir Effect, Hawking Radiation, etc.
widgets.prose: In Quantum Physics, Action is no longer always minimal. In fact it is almost never minimal, but strays from the minimum with a certain probability that depends on how far it strays. So the Polonium nucleus here has an alpha particle wandering about inside that has a probability of leaking outside of the nucleus causing the whole thing to fall apart, even though that would require briefly breaking energy conservation. Yes, shocking things happen when you violate the Minimal Action Principle. Or two metal plates in space start attracting each other due to virtual photons, which spontaneously arise from the vacuum for a brief interval of time, violating energy conservation, before disappearing again. But during their brief lifetime they cause the plates to attract. And other things you may have heard of like Hawking Radiation, there is a huge list of weird Quantum Physics phenomena. The thing is, no one is really comfortable with Quantum Physics. Even Nature is uncomfortable with it which is why the departures from the Minimal Action are so small (controlled by something called Planck's Constant, which in standard units is on the order of 10^-34 Joule-seconds.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/pipe.png
widgets.title: This is Why Safety First
widgets.notes:
The lowest order (classical) solution should be paramount 
 Then add perturbations (quantum) as needed
widgets.prose: So Nature is usually classical, that is what we see, but with a little quantum wiggling around. Like when you walk down a pipe, you stay at the bottom right? You don't go up and down the sides too much unless you're a sk8er or a rebel. But that's alright in moderation, in units of Planck's constant. The point is that Safety is like Classical Physics: it's what you want most of the time, otherwise the world would be too crazy.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/banking.png
widgets.title: A Banking Analogy
widgets.subtitle: (don't spend what you don't have)
widgets.notes:
Classical: buy only what you can afford 
 Quantum: use credit (in moderation ... that's why Planck's Constant is small!)
widgets.prose: In fact, there's a nice banking analogy I often used in my classes to explain the difference between Classical and Quantum Physics. Classical Physics is like only taking money out of the bank that you have. Quantum Physics is like taking a loan. Most of the time we do the former, but Nature, like a good financier, is an inventive opportunist and sees the use cases for wanting to borrow money sometimes, as long as it's paid back. And I think with any new technology like AI we need to be like prudent consumers.

children.prose: So anyways what's the Urgency here? Why should we be very, very motivated to discuss this?

Well I ask you, how many of you were taken surprise by ChatGPT? Just by show of hands or comments. And how many of you are still struggling to keep up with it? Well what if this talk was being given 5 years ago and I told you the ChatGPT moment was coming? Wouldn't you have liked to know that?

widgets.name: /INFORMS/failed.png

widgets.subtitle: (not)
widgets.notes: copious media attention to this, e.g., https://www.wired.com/story/facebooks-virtual-assistant-m-is-dead-so-are-chatbots/
widgets.prose: I mean it wasn't too long ago, and people were very down on chatbots, calling it a failed revolution and so on.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/chatgpt.png
widgets.title: The next ChatGPT Moment
widgets.prose: But then look at the technological adoption just a year later, the fastest in recorded history of any technology including the telephone, the internet, smartphones, you name it.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/chatgpt-warnings.png
widgets.title: Warnings and Precursors to the ChatGPT Moment
widgets.notes:
BERT 
 GAN
widgets.prose: And to be sure there were precursors, warning signs if you will. We had transformer technology, afterall, and I was even working on a financial chatbot using BERT in a very limited domain with some success. We had GAN models that could generate human faces (remember thispersondoesnotexist.com ?) which definitely raised eyebrows and probably led to more than a few fake IDs.

children.prose: Well with that in mind get ready for the next big revolution, what I call the Robo Moment --- this is going to rock the very foundations of society 100x or more than chatGPT did. We're going to suddenly have robots in the home, robots at work, robots on the street. Everywhere.
And like with ChatGPT there are warning signs and precursors right now if you look. I mean it's really hard to imagine things progressing more efficiently than they are now.

widgets.title: Agentic AI
widgets.notes:
• Agentic AI is about organizing AI 

 • Similar to industrial organization early 1900s 

 • Like the app store revolution for iPhones
widgets.prose: First, you've had self-driving vehicles and drones in civilian and military uses for quite a few years now -- because let's face it, hardware is hard to get right and disastrous if you get wrong because the effects are physical. In the meantime we've quietly been devising ways for AI systems to talk to each other, and that's what this rise of Agentic AI in the last year or so has been about.

children.prose: And humanoid robots have been developing very noticeably, maybe because we're more attuned or perhaps threatened by it.

children.prose: But why the focus on humanoid robots anyways? Well humans have been debating this for as long as we've had the word robotics, which Isaac Asimov invented by the way early last century, and in one of his books he even spells out the logic in favor of humanoid vs. specialized robots.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/asimov-humanoid.png
widgets.title: Asimov's Argument
widgets.notes:
⦿  Infrastructure can help them 

 ⦿  They can help the Infrastructure 

 ⦿  Social Acceptance
widgets.prose: What it comes down to, speaking through the characters in his books, is that humans have already devised a massive infrastructure that is made for humans -- so having a robot that is humanoid means you don't have to change any infrastructure, and moreover the robots can help us optimize that infrastructure for both humans and robots at the same time. Contrast to the need to develop a specialized robot for every domain, which itself may be shifting, and that's not scalable.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/life-humanoid.png
widgets.title: We like it? (see integration below)
widgets.prose: Also, there is the somewhat slippery reason of social acceptance, which is our desire yet our fear at the same time. We want robots to fit in to the society we've already built, but at the same time it is disturbing to have to share it with them, as we have to worry about the dividing lines between human and robot. Asimov again dealt with many situations like this in his books, with Robotic Politicans, Spouses, and so on, all with their certain advantages.

children.prose: Now that being said about the inevitability of humanoid robots, we will have a pandoras box to deal with in terms of robotic rights and priveleges. I recently chatted with a fellow at the UN who told me they are indeed working on a Universal Declaration of Robotic Rights. I mean look at how we treat robots today:

children.prose: Now I won't delve too much into this possibility, except to point out that there's an excellent argument, again from Asimov, that if and when we make contact with an intelligent alient civilization, it will probably be not with them, but their robots.

children.node: How do we deal with this?
children.prose: Next I'm going to dive into practical ways we can deal with the impending robotic revolution, and as you see we're sort of in the second big branch of this talk.

Well you've probably already read a lot about these words: Controls and Bounds (or guardrails) and Accountability, central tenets of Responsible AI. But you know, Responsible AI can have a nebulous air to it, so what can you really do about it?

children.pose: Well in terms of raw governance, I think we've seen that this is not very effective --- I mean the politicians themselves barely understand AI, so they don't really know how to govern it. Indeed, even Asimov conceded implicitly that his 3 Laws of Robotics were woefully insufficient. Guardrails to keep AI in line are likewise very fragile.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/predictive_AI.png
widgets.title: Traditional Metrics
widgets.prose: That just leaves us with traditional metrics, which are pretty weak and outdated for things like LLMs.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/irobot.png
widgets.title: The Three Laws of Robotics
widgets.subtitle: (Asimov, 1942)
widgets.notes:
1. A robot may not injure a human being or, through inaction, allow a human being to come to harm. 
 2. A robot must obey the orders given it by human beings except where such orders would conflict with the First Law. 
 3. A robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with the First or Second Law.

children.prose: So a bit of a pitch for myself here, IronAction is about keeping AI in line with rock solid, well iron solid, mathematical principles. Because I believe at the end of the day, truth and righteousness is mathematical, so let's see if we can find a suitable mathematical framework to keep AI in line.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/ironaction.jpeg
widgets.title: IronAction AI
widgets.notes:
Iron: the most stable element in the universe 
 Action: average (PE - KE), optimal dynamic

widgets.name: /INFORMS/harmonic.png
widgets.title: Manifold of Safety
widgets.subtitle: (start with Harmonic Functions)
widgets.notes:
Stable 
 Predictable 
 Minimal
widgets.prose: I define something which I call the Manifold of Safety. If AI is on this manifold, great. If not, we best do something about it. Ok so that's all very abstract, but how do we proceed. Well it turns out that Harmonic Manifolds are very nice. They have the minimal curvature required to fit training data, and it's easy to test if a machine learning system is harmonic or not by this so-called Mean Value Property. And yes this is really amazing but it's true, that the function is equal to the average value of all the points around it. So if you think about it, this is very nice because it's minimal (the machine learning or AI only models what it has to, not extra hallucination stuff) and it's easy to check with the Mean Value Property, which also provides explainability.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/harmonic_examples.png
widgets.title: Nature Likes Harmonic Functions
widgets.subtitle: (the laziness principle)
widgets.notes:
Minimizing Surface Tension 
 Heat Exchange 
 Electrostatic Potential Drop
widgets.prose: Now Nature actually like Harmonic Functions, probably for similar reasons. Soap films, electrostatic potentials, heat distributions, these are all described with Harmonic Functions.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/harmonic_measure.png
widgets.title: Direct Application to Machine Learning
widgets.subtitle: (this is OPEN SOURCE: https://github.com/nkersting/harmonic_robustness)
widgets.notes:
Training/Validation 
 Drift Detection 
 Real-time Monitoring
widgets.prose: This is actually directly applicable to machine learning, which I leave as open source.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/blackbox.png
widgets.title: Blackbox Metrics
widgets.subtitle: (everyone must be empowered to measure safety)
widgets.notes:
Simple 
 Affordable 
 Effective
widgets.prose: And I note this is also a blackbox technique, because in the robotic future we won't know what system is inside the robot --- we need model agnostic techniques to gauge whether the AI is trustworthy or not.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/empower.png
widgets.title: Empowering Everyone
widgets.subtitle: (again comes through safety)
widgets.notes:
Humanity 
 Self-worth 
 Motivation 
 Ambition
widgets.prose: Ultimately, what this is all about is giving us an assured and meaningful future.

children.prose: Now another thing we can do to help stay in control is make sure that we understand the reason  behind any AI decisions
This has been dubbed XAI in the literature, and is a rapidly burgeoning field of itself.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/explainable_ai2.png
widgets.title: What is an Explanation?
widgets.notes:
⦿  To whom? (age, language, culture, education, etc.) 

 ⦿  What kind? 
    ‣  causal: 'The daytime is warmer because the Earth has rotated to face the Sun' 
    ‣ deep scientific: '... because the greater intensity of high-energy photons impinges on ...' 
     ‣ religious: '... because God wanted us to wake up and serve Him 
    ‣ existential/anthropic:  '... because if it weren't, intelligent Life would not have developed to ponder this question'
widgets.prose: First of all, what constitutes an explanation? Most critically, to whom? People come from all kinds of backgrounds so you'll probably have to have a way to translate among explanations, itself a non-trivial task. Then there's the question of what kind of explanation you want.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/traditional_explain.png
widgets.title: Traditional Explainability
widgets.subtitle: (sometimes the model provides)
widgets.prose: But I think at least this audience can agree on Mathematics as a suitable explainer. There are models, for example, that just make mathematical sense: the Linear Regression, i.e. curve-fitting, which makes sense as the best curve between the points, or the Logistic Regression and Naive Bayes with probabilistic interpretations, or more logic-based decision trees and rule-based systems. Notably not, however Neural Nets, at least not to the same degree of explainability as these other models.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/general_explain.png
widgets.title: General Techniques
widgets.subtitle: (still traditionally-based)
widgets.notes:
LIME 
 SHAP 
 Saliency Maps
widgets.prose: And there are general techniques for any model, most notably SHAP and LIME, which basically attribute model predictions to how much they are controlled by individual features.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/stability.png
widgets.title: Stability as a proxy for Explainability
widgets.subtitle: (e.g., Harmoniticity)
widgets.notes:
Predictions on a Manifold that we Trust 
 Harmonic Functions are explainable and minimal
widgets.prose: Another mathematical type of explainability is through stability. We've talked before, for example, on Harmonic Stability.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/harmonic_ML.png
widgets.title: Harmonic Machine Learning
widgets.subtitle: (a principle for explainability)
widgets.notes:
Measure departure from harmoniticity 
 Useful as a validation metric 
 Useful in real-time drift detection
widgets.prose: And here you can see it in action on a real machine learning problem.

children.node: How do you want them to explain?
children.prose: I'll just note here that two traditional tests of explainability, the Chinese Room and the Turing Test, have both become outdated or moot thought experiments in the face of recent rapid LLM progress.

But they do set up the interesting philosophical question of whether LLMs actually think, which is interesting to me only because I see at least two promising mathematical directions that provide some positive evidence for this

widgets.name: /INFORMS/grok.png
widgets.title: Stranger in a Strange Land
widgets.prose: First, there is the phenomenon of Grokking, a term invented by this classic sci-fi novel, which manifests itself as a sudden ability of the LLM to generalize beyond its training data, which is a sort of Hegelian qualitative effect brought about by scale.

children.prose: Then you have another effect that has been emerging for a number of years, which is that when you cast words into numbers, there is a sort of interpolative logic that emerges as a de facto simulation of thought'.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/manifold.png
widgets.title: The Manifold of Truth
widgets.prose: But if it does, then this is huge. It means that human knowledge and logic, everything you can possibly say that is not contradictory or false, lives on a higher dimensional manifold, the Manifold of Truth. And it is in this sense that LLMs can think -- they are exploring this manifold every time we use them.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/vector-embedding.png
widgets.title: Words to Vectors
widgets.prose: Take word embeddings, for example. It has long been observed that there are more than coincidental, almost eerie logical connections established among words without the model being explicitly told to do so. Now as a reminder that back in 2014 or so these word embeddings were originally trained with nothing more than statistical co-occurence: you initialize all the embeddings to random vectors and then feed billions of phrases and non-phrases with instructions to a neural net to output 1 if the phrase is real, 0 if fake. And the embeddings gradually converge. Now when all your embeddings converge you stop the process and look: you have vector algebra among the vectors exhibiting real logic. In fact if you didn't know the word 'man', you could predict it by 'queen-woman+king'. Presumably this 'AI' is able to predict new words with real logical meaning we haven't even thought of. And that's budding intelligences, i.e., kids, do!

widgets.name: /INFORMS/vector-sequence.png
widgets.title: Measuring the Manifold
widgets.prose: Now what I've just discussed is old hat. What I'm about to discuss is cutting edge and likely to prove a very powerful tool within the near future. So consider a sentence, which is a sequence of words, right? It traces out a trajectory in embedding space.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/vector-sequences.png
widgets.title: The Age of Interpolation
widgets.subtitle: discovering ourselves
widgets.notes:
LLMs are giving us ideas 'between the lines'

widgets.prose: Now consider many such sentences in our training data, say. They start to carve out a portion of embedding space, which I call the manifold. Now it's kind of a wireframe of a manifold, because these lines are discrete 1-dimensional surfaces tracing through the very high dimensional space. But in between the lines are other possible lines which are probably logically consistent. So between 'I like to run' and 'People enjoy walking' is a trajectory which corresponds to say 'She likes to jog'. And so on. This is a conjecture, by the way, that this manifold really exists.

children.prose: But now speaking of Truth, let's consider the opposite, which has become known as Hallucination. It's not an ideal term, but it basically stands for at least two kinds of false information: 1. when the LLM is so confident it knows the answer but really it has no knowledge about the topic and is just making stuff up, and 2. when the LLM should have the information it needs but gives you garbage instead. Either one of these possibilities is straying from the manifold of truth, which however, is also trained on garbage, also gives you a third type of hallucination where the LLM is just telling you what you trained it on, so I'm sure you've heard the phrase 'garbage in, garbage out'.

children.prose: So what's my Proposal?

First of all, it's important to remember that Humans are still in control, so we have first-movers advantage. In order to safely integrate AI into our society, let's apply natural safeguards, things that can't really fail, because AI has no way to change physics.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/natural_safeguards.png
widgets.title: Physical Limits
widgets.notes:
• We trust things which are naturally constrained 

 • 'Dont Be There' is one of the 'extra' 36 miliary stratgems of Sun Tzu 

 • e.g. we trust Target shoppers to buy knives because their destructive power is very limited (relative to the car they drive to get there) 

 • We trust drivers will not cross the yellow line because of strong negative motivation
widgets.prose: so you know, the first natural safeguard is plate glass, keep AI well contained as long as possible.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/natural_safeguards2.png
widgets.title: Manifolds of Truth
widgets.notes: • Mathematical safeguards are even better
widgets.prose: And instill some mathematical guarantees it will stay in bounds. Or at least give ourselves the power to measure that. Remember my Recalibration principle --- we're always checking whether AI is within bounds, and correcting it if not.

widgets.name: /INFORMS/natural_safeguards3.png
widgets.title: Expiration
widgets.prose: Expiration is also a natural bound. Like radioactive items, incredibly dangerous but by their very nature they get weaker over time. We CAN let AI expire. Don't build it to last. We can always rebuild it if needed, and probably better than before.

children.prose: Remember my other maxim, A Backup Plan for Everything. Well, keep low-tech around. Because if AI fails, every other high-tech system will be unreliable. Only the ancient technology will be resistant.

Finally, and this is no joke, Kung-fu, not just the martial art but the spirit to do good, that is tantamount to my principle of Loose Coupling --- AI may fail in a million ways, but you keep the core goal of doing good, and being efficient, that will smooth over any hiccups in development.

Next we have to pay careful attention to how we communicate. Because let's not forget communication is central to humanity's progress throughout the millenia, from the spoken word, to the invention of writing, telegraph, telephone, and internet. We are a species that massively benefits from sharing ideas, and conversely atropies when we can't. But in the AI age we need to safeguard Privacy, Security, and Integrity.

Privacy is paramount in my mind -- historically we have safeguarded intellectual property from other humans, with a legal system to uphold that, but who's going to defend us if critical information is leaked to AI? Chances are that would lead to immediate loss of privacy with no one held accountable, at best, and at worst it could enable AI to monitor us and optimize its own survival over ours. Aside from low-tech solutions we mentioned earlier (like passing hand-written notes), do we also have technological solutions?

widgets.name: /INFORMS/haven.png
widgets.title: Haven
widgets.subtitle: Self-host a private blog instead of using Facebook
widgets.notes:
• Haven is an open-source, self-hosted blog designed as a private alternative to platforms like Facebook. It allows sharing posts and photos with a select group of invited peers, rather than the general public.

 • Complete User Control: Complete control of content, data, and access. There are no mechanism for ads, user tracking, or censorship of content. 

 • Invite-Only Access: The platform is inherently private and secure. There is no public directory or search function; users must be directly invited for access. 

 • Built-in Personal Feed: Haven includes a reader that allows creation of a curated feed of other websites and other Havens, free from algorithms and advertisements. 

 • Aligned incentives: The user controls the platform. There are no vectors for misaligned incentives between the user and service-provider (eg. Facebook/Tiktok engagement-hacking)
widgets.prose: And here's another type of solution developed by my friend and fellow PCI colleague, Matt Wise. Which is to say you completely decouple from something like FB managing your content visibility.

widgets.prose: Now in the course of my exploration I found it useful to define Energy. This isn't quite the physical energy we learn in physics, though it is motivated by it. For example, looking at these two musical compositions, it is apparent that Beethoven's notes move around a lot less than the AI-generated music. It has less Energy. How do we quantify that? ... so we see that Fur Elise has less energy, but a higher V/E. This pattern seems to be repeated across various human-generated vs. AI-generated media, for example text, and images. My hypothesis, therefore, is that V/E is a measure of humanity, because we're good at it. So, what are we going to do with that?

children.prose: For one thing, Art. Now, I wrote a short treatise on what is Art, Science, and Math. Because they're all related. Art is arbitrariness. The Mona Lisa is Art becuase you can change her a little bit and it is still acceptable. Math is the opposite. You can't change the Pythagorean Theorem, not one iota. And Science is the process of Art becoming Math. If you haven't read Robert Persig's book, a classic, well it's similarly confirming this: Art is anything you put your mind to that has space to explore; and that's why we have so many title like 'zen and the art of xyz'.

widgets.prose: Now why are humans always going to be better than machines at Art? First of all, we are very random, messy biological computer-animals. No metallic computer can compete with that degree of ambiguity. And we  have finite lifespans and a tradition of passing on knowledge to our offspring --- every generation has a different zeitgeist, and thus the pool of social beliefs keeps churning and spewing out new things. Computers can also beget other computers but there is a priori no limit to their lifespans, so they stagnate. This is actually also Asimov's argument why humans are so good at taking over the galaxy versus other lifeforms with long stable lives and few offspring.
